title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of STIs & Syndromic Management
topicName: Unit Six: STIs and HIV AIDS
description: Assess your understanding of the syndromic approach to STI diagnosis, common syndromes, and key management principles.

questions.question: What is the primary basis for the 'Syndromic Approach' to STI diagnosis adopted in Kenya?

options.text: Isolation of causative organisms in a laboratory
Diagnosis based on groups of signs and symptoms
Diagnosis based solely on patient history
Diagnosis based on blood serology only

questions.explanation: The syndromic approach diagnoses conventional STIs on the basis of syndromes (a group of signs and symptoms) rather than by the causative organisms, which is useful in low-resource settings.
questions.hint: Think about how STIs are grouped clinically without a microscope.

questions.question: Which of the following are included in the 'Four C's' of STI management? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Four C's are: Counselling, Compliance (adherence to medication), Condoms (promotion/provision), and Contact Tracing.
questions.hint: One C relates to taking medication correctly, another to partners.

questions.question: Match the STI Syndrome with its characteristic signs:

pairs.right: Genital sore, Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes
Swollen eyelids, Purulent discharge in newborn

questions.explanation: Different syndromes present with distinct physical signs. GUD involves sores; Ophthalmia affects eyes; PID involves abdominal pain.
questions.hint: Match the location of the symptom to the syndrome name.

questions.question: What is the term for a group of signs and symptoms that occur together and characterize a particular abnormality?
questions.explanation: A syndrome simply means a group of signs and symptoms. This is the foundation of the Syndromic Approach.

questions.question: Review the Aetiology Table below. Which organisms are commonly associated with Cervicitis? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content:
SyndromeMost Common Aetiology
VaginitisTrichomonas, Candida, Bacterial vaginosis
CervicitisGonorrhoea, Chlamydia
Genital UlcerSyphilis, Chancroid, Herpes

questions.explanation: According to the table and study material, Cervicitis is commonly caused by Gonorrhoea and Chlamydia. Vaginitis is caused by Trichomonas and Candida.
questions.hint: Look at the second row of the table provided.

questions.question: Vaginal discharge caused by Vaginitis has fewer severe long-term consequences than discharge caused by Cervicitis.
questions.explanation: True. Vaginitis is painful but has fewer severe consequences. Cervicitis (Gonorrhea/Chlamydia) can lead to PID, infertility, and ectopic pregnancy.
questions.hint: Cervicitis involves the cervix and can ascend to internal organs.

questions.question: A key component of compliance is avoiding ___BLANK___ medication and ensuring the patient takes the ___BLANK___ dose prescribed.
questions.explanation: Patients must avoid self-medication and complete the full dose to prevent resistance and ensure cure.
questions.hint: One refers to treating oneself, the other to finishing the medicine.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the five main STI syndromes listed in the study material?
questions.explanation: Chronic headache is not an STI syndrome. The five are Vaginal discharge, Urethral discharge, Lower abdominal pain, Genital ulcer disease, and Ophthalmia neonatorum.
questions.hint: Which one is not related to the genital/reproductive system?

questions.question: Arrange the 4 C's logic in the order they might typically be addressed during a consultation:
questions.explanation: While they occur concurrently, the logical flow is: Counsel on condition -> Ensure treatment compliance -> Prevent spread (condoms) -> Treat partners.
questions.hint: You treat the patient first, then prevent future spread, then address partners.

questions.question: Read the case scenario below. What is the most appropriate immediate action?

richContent.content: Scenario: A male patient presents with a urethral discharge. He admits to having unprotected sex 5 days ago. He requests medication but refuses to inform his partner.

options.text: Refuse to treat him until he brings his partner
Treat him using the syndromic approach and counsel him on the importance of contact tracing
Report him to the local authorities
Give him a placebo until he agrees to counselling

questions.explanation: You must treat the patient promptly to prevent complications and transmission, while simultaneously counselling him on the 4 C's (including Contact Tracing) to encourage partner treatment.
questions.hint: Treatment should never be withheld, but education is crucial.
